THELGON.  CHROMIS.

THELGON.</br>Chromis my joy, why drop thy rainie eyes?</br>And sullen clouds hang on thy heavie brow?</br>Seems that thy net is rent, and idle lies;</br>Thy merry pipe hangs broken on a bough:</br>But late thy time in hundred joyes thou spent'st;</br>Now time spends thee, while thou in vain lament'st.

CHROMIS.</br>Thelgon, my pipe is whole, and nets are new:</br>But nets and pipe contemn'd, and idle lie:</br>My little reed, that late so merry blew,</br>Tunes sad notes to his masters miserie:</br>Time is my foe, and hates my rugged rimes:</br>And I as much hate both that hate, and times.

THELGON.</br>What is it then that causeth thy unrest?</br>Or wicked charms?  or loves new-kindled fire?</br>Ah!  much I fear love eats thy tender breast;</br>Too well I know his never quenched ire,</br>Since I Amyntas lov'd, who me disdains,</br>And loves in me nought but my grief and pains.

CHROMIS.</br>No lack of love did ever breed my smart:</br>I onely learn'd to pity others pain,</br>And ward my breast from his deceiving art:</br>But one I love, and he loves me again;</br>In love this onely is my greatest sore,</br>He loves so much, and I can love no more.

But when the fishers trade, once highly priz'd,</br>And justly honour'd in those better times,</br>By every lozel-groom I see despis'd;</br>No marvel if I hate my jocond rimes,</br>And hang my pipe upon a willow bough:</br>Might I grieve ever, if I grieve not now.

THELGON.</br>Ah foolish boy!  why should'st thou so lament</br>To be like him, whom thou dost like so well?</br>The Prince of fishers thousand tortures rent.</br>To heav'n, lad, thou art bound:  the way by hell.</br>Would'st thou ador'd, and great and merry be,</br>When he was mockt, debas'd, and dead for thee?

Mens scorns should rather joy, then sorrow move;</br>For then thou highest art, when thou art down.</br>Their storms of hate should more blow up my love;</br>Their laughters my applause, their mocks my crown.</br>Sorrow for him, and shame let me betide,</br>Who for me wretch in shame and sorrow died.

CHROMIS.</br>Thelgon, 'tis not my self for whom I plain,</br>My private losse full easie could I bear,</br>If private losse might help the publick gain:</br>But who can blame my grief, or chide my fear,</br>Since now the fishers trade, and honour'd name</br>Is made the common badge of scorn and shame?

Little know they the fishers toilsome pain,</br>Whose labour with his age, still growing, spends not:</br>His care and watchings (oft mispent in vain)</br>The early morn begins, dark evening ends not.</br>Too foolish men, that think all labour stands</br>In travell of the feet, and tired hands!

Ah wretched fishers!  born to hate and strife;</br>To others good, but to your rape and spoil.</br>This is the briefest summe of fishers life,</br>To sweat, to freeze, to watch, to fast, to toil,</br>Hated to love, to live despis'd, forlorn,</br>A sorrow to himself, all others scorn.

THELGON.</br>Too well I know the fishers thanklesse pain,</br>Yet bear it cheerfully, nor dare repine.</br>To grudge at losse is fond, (too fond and vain)</br>When highest causes justly it assigne.</br>Who bites the stone, and yet the dog condemnes,</br>Much worse is then the beast he so contemnes.

Chromis, how many fishers dost thou know,</br>That rule their boats, and use their nets aright?</br>That neither winde, nor time, nor tide foreslow?</br>Such some have been; but (ah!)  by tempests spite</br>Their boats are lost; while we may sit and moan,</br>That few were such, and now those few are none.

CHROMIS.</br>Ah cruel spite, and spitefull crueltie,</br>That thus hath robb'd our joy, and desert shore!</br>No more our seas shall heare your melodie;</br>Your songs and shrilling pipes shall sound no more:</br>Silent our shores, our seas are vacant quite.</br>Ah spitefull crueltie, and cruel spite!

THELGON.</br>In stead of these a crue of idle grooms,</br>Idle, and bold, that never saw the seas,</br>Fearlesse succeed, and fill their empty rooms:</br>Some lazy live, bathing in wealth and ease:</br>Their floating boats with waves have leave to play,</br>Their rusty hooks all yeare keep holy-day.

Here stray their skiffes, themselves are never here,</br>Ne're saw their boats:  ill mought they fishers be:</br>Mean time some wanton boy the boat doth steer,</br>(Poore boat the while!)  that cares as much as he:</br>Who in a brook a whirry cannot row,</br>Now backs the seas, before the seas he know.

CHROMIS.</br>Ah foolish lads, that think with waves to play,</br>And rule rough seas, which never knew command!</br>First in some river thy new skill assay,</br>Till time and practise teach thy weakly hand:</br>A thin, thin plank keeps in thy vitall breath:</br>Death ready waits.  Fond boyes, to play with death!

THELGON.</br>Some stretching in their boats supinely sleep,</br>Seasons in vain recall'd, and windes neglecting:</br>Other their hooks and baits in poison steep,</br>Neptune himself with deathfull drugges infecting:</br>The fish their life and death together drink,</br>And dead pollute the seas with venom'd stink.

Some teach to work, but have no hands to row:</br>Some will be eyes, but have no light to see:</br>Some will be guides, but have no feet to go:</br>Some deaf, yet eares; some dumbe, yet tongues will be:</br>Dumbe, deaf, lame, blinde, and maim'd; yet fishers all:</br>Fit for no use, but store an hospital.

Some greater, scorning now their narrow boat,</br>In mighty hulks and ships (like courts) do dwell;</br>Slaving the skiffes that in their seas do float;</br>Their silken sails with windes do proudly swell;</br>Their narrow bottomes stretch they large and wide,</br>And make full room for luxurie and pride.

Self did I see a swain not long ago,</br>Whose lordly ship kept all the rest in aw:</br>About him thousand boats do waiting row;</br>His frowns are death, his word is firmest law;</br>While all the fisher-boyes their bonnets vail,</br>And farre adore their lord with strucken sail.

His eare is shut to simple fisher-swain.</br>For Gemma's self (a sea-nymph great and high)</br>Upon his boat attended long in vain:</br>What hope, poore fisher-boy may come him nigh?</br>His speech to her, and presence he denied.</br>Had Neptune come, Neptune he had defied.

Where Tybers swelling waves his banks o'reflow,</br>There princely fishers dwell in courtly halls:</br>The trade they scorn, their hands forget to row;</br>Their trade, to plot their rising, others falls;</br>Into their seas to draw the lesser brooks,</br>And fish for steeples high with golden hooks.

CHROMIS.</br>Thelgon, how canst thou well that fisher blame,</br>Who in his art so highly doth excell,</br>That with himself can raise the fishers name?</br>Well may he thrive, that spends his art so well.</br>Ah, little needs their honour to depresse:</br>Little it is; yet most would have it lesse.

THELGON.</br>Alas poore boy!  thy shallow-swimming sight</br>Can never dive into their deepest art;</br>Those silken shews so dimme thy dazel'd sight.</br>Could'st thou unmask their pomp, unbreast their heart,</br>How would'st thou laugh at this rich beggerie!</br>And learn to hate such happy miserie!

Panting ambition spurres their tired breast:</br>Hope chain'd to doubt, fear linkt to pride and threat,</br>(Too ill yok't pairs) give them no time to rest;</br>Tyrants to lesser boats, slaves to the great.</br>That man I rather pity, then adore,</br>Who fear'd by others much, fears others more.

Most cursed town, where but one tyrant reignes:</br>(Though lesse his single rage on many spent)</br>But much more miserie that soul remains,</br>When many tyrants in one heart are pent:</br>When thus thou serv'st, the comfort thou canst have</br>From greatnesse is, thou art a greater slave.

CHROMIS.</br>Ah wretched swains, that live in fishers trade;</br>With inward griefs, and outward wants distressed;</br>While every day doth more your sorrow lade;</br>By others scorn'd, and by your selves oppressed!</br>The great the greater serve, the lesser these:</br>And all their art is how to rise and please.

THELGON.</br>Those fisher-swains, from whom our trade doth flow,</br>That by the King of seas their skill were taught;</br>As they their boats on Jordan wave did row,</br>And catching fish, were by a Fisher caught;</br>(Ah blessed chance!  much better was the trade,</br>That being fishers, thus were fishes made).

Those happy swains, in outward shew unblest,</br>Were scourg'd, were scorn'd, yet was this losse their gain:</br>By land, by sea, in life, in death, distrest;</br>But now with King of seas securely reigne:</br>For that short wo in this base earthly dwelling,</br>Enjoying joy all excellence excelling.

Then do not thou, my boy, cast down thy minde,</br>But seek to please with all thy busie care</br>The King of seas; so shalt thou surely finde</br>Rest, quiet, joy, in all this troublous fare.</br>Let not thy net, thy hook, thy singing cease:</br>And pray these tempests may be turn'd to peace.

Oh Prince of waters, Soveraigne of seas,</br>Whom storms and calms, whom windes and waves obey;</br>If ever that great Fisher did thee please,</br>Chide thou the windes, and furious waves allay:</br>So on thy shore the fisher-boys shall sing</br>Sweet songs of peace to our sweet peaces King.</br>
